table_of_contents: T端rkiye 2024-2025 Economic Environment and Company ABC Overview

points: Company ABC operates the Earthquake Scheme, established to cover damages caused by earthquakes to residential properties. This reinsurance contract will continue to provide earthquake only cover for residential properties.
With the introduction of inflation indexed policies, 2024 has seen a compounded effect of doubling of policy limits and indexation. This in line with forecasts provided at the 2023/4 renewal.
For 2024/5, this compounding will no longer be present leading to a reduction in the growth of aggregates YoY compared to previous two years.
Over the course of the existence of the pool the overall reinsurance balance remains positive with nearly 10% payback.
Following further validation, we have maintained the Revised View of Risk for this year, with the updated higher vulnerability curve and amended hazard module in line with latest scientific research.

sections.section_title: T端rkiye 2024-2025: Economic Environment and Company ABC Overview

points: T端rkiye's economy has begun to stabilise driven by changes in monetary policy after a period of economic uncertainty.
Following changes within the Central Bank and Finance ministry in March, T端rkiye has begun to take a different economic course.
Priorities include tightening monetary policy, controlling inflation, and sustaining real term economic growth for TRY stability.
The disinflation process started in June is projected to continue with a stronger pace.
In 2024, TRY to EUR exchange rate has largely stabilised (increased by only 3% since March).
Turkish Central Bank estimates inflation will decrease to ~38% at 2024 year-end, and forecast to fall to 14% for year-end 2025.

content.footnote: Company ABC's portfolio and reinsurance programme is solely in TRY, unlike other Turkish Broker ABC placements, meaning no currency volatility affects the structure.

points: Company ABC's reinsurance will continue to provide cover for residential properties and EQ only for 2024/25.
Potential legislative changes (e.g., inclusion of contents and/or additional perils) are uncertain but not covered by the current contract.
Compulsory Earthquake Insurance (Law no. 6305) covers residential buildings within municipality borders.
Company ABC indemnifies for material damages caused by earthquakes and directly resulting fires, explosions, tsunami, and landslides within policy limits.

Covered building parts include: Foundations, Main walls, Common walls, Garden walls, Retaining walls, Ceilings, Basements, Stairs, Elevators, Platforms, Corridors, Roofs, Chimneys, and similar supplementary sections.
Indemnity amount is determined by dwelling size and style, up to the maximum sum insured.
The end of step-change limits and introduction of inflation-adjusted policy limits leads to stabilization.

Worked Example Logic: Government doubled limits (TRY 640,000 to TRY 1,272,000) from Jan 1, 2024. This doubling, compounded with monthly indexation, caused significant exposure growth in 2023/24 (reaching an estimated TRY 1,760,745 by Dec 2024).
From 2025 onwards (2024/25 period), the impact is limited to monthly inflation tracking only (estimated limit TRY 2,073,816 by Oct 2025, representing +18% increase from Dec 2024 estimate).
Turkish Producer Price Index (PPI) is used as the indexation factor.
Stabilisation in policy limit growth is expected in the following contract period due to the absence of the initial doubling effect.

points: The Court final legal precedent found in favour of Company ABC, resulting in a reduction in required Outstanding claims reserves.
The Court concluded that Company ABC's liability is limited to the insurance amount stated in the policy and no double limit would be applied.
The court dismissed appeal objections and upheld the previous decision, confirming Company ABC fulfilled its responsibilities per policy and legal regulations.
Recent earthquake raised concerns about industry-standard model performance in the region.
Region A: Predicted shaking intensities aligned well with observed data.
Region B: Significant underestimation occurred due to the unmodeled Valley Amplification Effect.

Impact of Underestimation: Discrepancies in ground movement predictions affect damage estimates (e.g., high-rise steel building MDR predicted 50% at 0.9g PGA, actual 78% at 1.4g PGA). Loss expectations were significantly understated.
Unpriced Risk: Areas with underestimated seismic activity may have inadequate/mispriced coverage. Regions like Metropolitan X (less amplification) may not face the same risk adjustments.
Adjustments to Risk Models: Industry assessments suggest model vulnerability curves may be understated, particularly at moderate intensity levels (partial structural failures).
Comparison with Y's seismic research showed a higher vulnerability index.
An updated risk framework (Revised View of Risk) incorporating higher vulnerability and amended hazard module is maintained for 2025.
